awd_titl_txt: Conscious separateness, unanticipated convergence: World Englishes
awd_abstract_narration:
Work in creole studies tends to focus on the relationship of a pidgin/creole to its lexifier language and to concentrate on morphosyntax to the exclusion of other components of the grammar. The present study broadens creole studies/contact linguistics by examining the relationship of two vernaculars to each other rather than to their lexifier and by bringing phonetics/phonology into the picture. In the context of research on variation and change in contact languages, this study is innovative in its two comparisons: language use of two co-existing contact varieties are compared to each other, and recorded data from an earlier time period are compared to current speech patterns. This project contributes to the documentation of under-studied varieties of English. It has the potential to link to research on World Englishes and their diachronic development.

This research project takes place in Liberia. Kolokwa (< colloquial) is the pidginized vernacular of the indigenous majority; it is a modern descendant of West African Pidgin English. Liberian Settler English (LSE) is the other; it came to Liberia as nineteenth-century African American English, The two varieties have been in close contact for almost two centuries, but the vexed, often antagonistic, relationship of the speakers has promoted the separateness of the two varieties. Even with recent political upheaval, the country's linguistic ideology has remained largely intact, particularly in its stigmatization of Kolokwa. The researcher, Dr. John Singler, compiled parallel corpora of sociolinguistic interviews in 1988-1989, just before civil war broke out in Liberia: one was with LSE speakers, the other with Kolokwa speakers. In terms of morphosyntactic features, while each variety has taken from the other, by and large features from the language of the powerful group, LSE, have spread to the language of the disenfranchised, Kolokwa. For phonetics/phonology, the direction appears to be reversed. A pilot study based on part of each corpus makes the case that Kolokwa had a seven-vowel system and that LSE has gone from the twelve-vowel system of nineteenth-century African American English to Kolokwa's seven-vowel system. Dr. Singler will expand the study to include all the speakers (24 Kolokwa, 16 LSE) and further to look at variable coda-consonant deletion. Moreover, because the LSE corpus comes from an atypical Settler community, a new LSE corpus from a more representative settlement will be generated. Entree into this LSE community will be achieved through interaction with its quilting group. While carrying out his collection of the new corpus, Dr. Singler will discuss the relationship of Kolokwa and LSE in the media and in public forums, in particular to demonstrate the ways in which the two ostensibly distinct varieties have each given features to the other, producing a distinctively Liberian result.

por.por_cntn:
Liberia has two nonstandard Englishes: Liberian Settler English (LSE) and Kolokwa. LSE owes its origin to nineteenth-century African American English. It is the language of the descendants of the 16,000 African Americans who immigrated to Liberia in the 1800s. Kolokwa is the English-lexifier variety spoken by Liberians of indigenous heritage. The Liberian descendant of the pidgin that arose along the West African coast in the eighteenth century, Kolokwa is now a creole, the native language of many people and the main language in the capital Monrovia.

The grant studied the relationship between LSE and Kolokwa, with particular attention to the vowel system of each variety. The data came from two corpora of sociolinguistic interviews from the late 1980s. The Sinoe Settler Corpus comprised fifteen interviews with elderly Settlers living 250 miles down the coast from Monrovia. A community member conducted most of the interviews. The Lakpazee Kolokwa Corpus comprised 24 interviews with residents of a Monrovia neighborhood. In this instance, a community member conducted all the interviews.

For the acoustic measurement of vowels, a sequence of mechanical programs was employed. Digital transcription was force-aligned, i.e. the beginning and end points of vowels were determined automatically, and the vowels extracted. This process presents large numbers of vowels for analysis. After refining the sets by removing certain types of vowels, e.g. those whose formants would be profoundly altered by their adjacency to particular consonants, we had 10,508 stressed vowels from the Sinoe Settler Corpus and 13,955 from the Lakpazee Kolokwa Corpus.

We hypothesized that the vowel system that the original Settlers brought with them had been transmitted over time to the current LSE speakers. (Historical evidence points to what that initial vowel system would have been.) The Kolokwa speakers all had an additional first language, a Niger-Congo language, and we proposed that the Kolokwa vowel system would be analogous to the vowel system of Monrovia Niger-Congo languages. The Niger-Congo system lacks four vowels that we posited as being present in the original Settler system: the vowels in TRAP, STRUT, FOOT, and KIT. Drawing on Bhattacharyya's Affinity, a statistical measure of overlap between two populations, in this case pairs of vowels, we found that in Kolokwa each one of these 'foreign' vowels merged with a neighboring vowel: TRAP with LOT, STRUT with THOUGHT, FOOT with GOAT, and KIT with FACE. Turning to LSE, we found that three of the four Kolokwa mergers had now occurred there as well. Only TRAP had remained distinct.  In sum, contact with Kolokwa speakers had resulted in LSE adoption of Kolokwa vowel mergers.

For two kindred varieties in ongoing contact, it is unremarkable if one variety takes on features from the other.  What is noteworthy in the present case arises from the attitudes of LSE speakers towards Kolokwa and its speakers. From the arrival of the Settlers early in the nineteenth century onward, the Settlers have seen themselves and their language as superior. Consequently, one would expect that the Settlers would resist any incorporation of Kolokwa features into LSE. We propose that the reason why these changes occurred is that vowel systems are not particularly salient. LSE speakers display no awareness that they have moved their vowel system to be more like that of Kolokwa.

The sociolinguist William Labov proposes that there are two types of linguistic change. One occurs within a speech community across the transmission of a language from generation to generation. This type is designated 'change from below,' as it is below the level of speakers' consciousness. The other type, diffusion, introduces change from outside the speech community by the adoption of features from a more prestigious variety. This is 'change from above,' as it is above the level of speakers' consciousness. This paradigm assumes, then, that change from below the level of speakers' consciousness is necessarily change from within, while change from without is always change from above. We propose that the LSE vowel changes represent speech from without that is nevertheless speech from below, a relationship not countenanced in Labov's paradigm.

In addition to the two corpora used for the vowel analysis, the grant created a third corpus for use in future research. The Bensonville Quiltmakers Corpus consists of 36 sociolinguistic interviews with quiltmakers from the settlement of Bensonville, twenty miles outside Monrovia, and from quilting groups established in Greater Monrovia by Bensonville quiltmakers displaced during the Liberian civil war. Two senior quiltmakers conducted these interviews. In addition, five quilting sessions were recorded. The Bensonville Quiltmakers Corpus differed from the previous corpora because of the passage of time and the impact of widespread displacement. Moreover, where the Sinoe Settler Corpus consisted only of Settlers and the Lakpazee Kolokwa Corpus only of people from indigenous ethnic groups, the Bensonville Quiltmakers Corpus consists of Settlers and indigenous people alike.
